bibl.title: Letter from Robert Carter to John King, September 12, 1723

div1.p: Robert Carter writes to Bristol merchant John King, September 12, 1723, to alert him to a bill of exchange he has drawn to Nicholas Smith and requesting an account current with the goods he ordered previously.

div1.head: Letter from Robert Carter to John King, September 12, 1723

opener.dateline:
Rappahannock, [Lancaster County, Virginia]
Sept. 12th. 1723—
Mr. John King

div1.p:
The only Occasion of this is to advise You that Just
Now I have drawn a bill of Exche. upon You payble to Majr. Nicho.
Smith for £17. who is now at much house & was desirous of having
this money in Your hands, by a former Lettr. I writ to You for
a Small parcell of Goods, with which I hope You will Send me an
Accot. Currt. I shall Give You no further trouble at present but
to Subscribe
div1.closer:
Sir Yor. very humble Servt.
per the [omission in text]of Bristol

div1.head: NOTES
div1.note: Source copy consulted: Robert Carter letter book, 1723 June 16-1724 April 23, Robert Carter Papers (acc. no. 3807), Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia.

Robert Carter generally used a return address of "Rappahannock" for the river on which he lived rather than "Corotoman," the name of his home, on his correspondence, especially to merchants abroad. The county and colony have been added for clarity.
